title: Unicode question (U+0315)
content:
I'm wondering if anyone know the intended use of U+0315, called COMBINING COMMA ABOVE RIGHT. Is this glyph intended to be used to represent ejectives/implosives in languages which use an apostrophe to indicate glottalization, or is it intended to represent the alternate form of the haček found in pairs like Ď ~ ď? While the former will always resemble the apostrophe, the latter can differ significantly depending on typeface, so I'm wondering which form should ideally be used.

André
author: agisaak

comments.content:
When an apostrophe is used to indicate a glottal stop, that is regarded as a separate letter and thus not an accent mark. However, a transformation of a consonant could be indicated by an accent, such as palatalization, so if there is such a thing as glottalization...

Ah, yes, Wikipedia tells me that glotallic consonants are represented with an apostrophe in the IPA.

U+0315 was added to Unicode in version 1.1, and is a combining diacritical mark. But I can't find the original proposal for adding it to Unicode.

> ...is it intended to represent the alternate form of the haček found in pairs like Ď ~ ď?

Yes. U+0315 is provided for compatibility with visual encodings that handled e.g. ď with a separate character from the normal haček. It's mostly useful these days as a component glyph for use in making diacritic composites for Czech and Slovak glyph sets. Note that although nominally a combining mark it actually requires an advance width, so is not usually handled with GPOS dynamic mark positioning.

The glottal stop, when so signaled using one fairly common orthography, uses the "raised comma," U+02BC. But remember, that's just one orthography. In Polynesian, the glottal stop is signaled with the turned comma, U+02BB, as in Hawai‘i. And in some languages, the glottal stop itself is used.

> Note that although nominally a combining mark it actually requires an advance width

Where is that specified? Somewhere in [http://unicode.org/cldr/utility/character.jsp?a=0315](http://web.archive.org/web/20150420162209/http:/unicode.org/cldr/utility/character.jsp?a=0315 "http://unicode.org/cldr/utility/character.jsp?a=0315") ?

Thanks, John

That answers my question perfectly.

André
